awd_titl_txt: The Brain Basis of Emotion: A Category Construction Problem
awd_abstract_narration:
Emotions play a central role in human life, yet their neural basis remains poorly understood. Within the science of emotion, it is currently debated whether there is a common brain pattern for a specific emotion category, such as anger, sadness, or fear, or whether there is meaningful variation in the patterns within each category and similarity across categories. An interdisciplinary research team will develop innovative modeling algorithms to learn, rather than stipulate, the number of categories justified by the brain data of each participant. This innovative approach will yield fundamental insights into the nature of emotion in the brain. More broadly, the modeling techniques will provide a means for the human neuroscience community to flexibly investigate psychological categories, without imposing theory-laden assumptions on their data as to the nature of the categories. This work will also help lay the groundwork for a more context-sensitive, personalized approach for relating neural activity with psychological categories.

Standard classification approaches to analysis of neuroscience data assume that fixed, experimenter-assigned labels are representative of the ground truth. The present research will question these assumptions and investigate a novel hypothesis that understanding the brain basis of emotion is a category construction problem, not a classification problem. A classification problem assumes that the brain already represents the categories in question, whereas a category construction problem tests this assumption. This project will involve fMRI scanning as participants view emotional videos and subsequently rate their subjective experiences.  The research will extensively sample multiple instances of the same emotion category within an individual. The investigators will model the data as a category construction problem by flexibly testing and discovering latent constructs using unsupervised machine learning algorithms combined with empirical model order selection analyses. This research will allow for future researchers to more flexibly and reliably analyze fMRI data, opening up new intellectual schema for understanding how such data reflects brain organization and mental experience in the science of emotion and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How does the brain represent emotion? The answer to this question is important for understanding the nature of human experience and for developing translational approaches to increase health and well-being. Over the past decade, neuroscientists have used advanced statistical and machine learning approaches to understand how the brain represents emotion. However, different studies have shown different findings, and the reasons for these inconsistencies are unclear. It is often assumed that discrepancies across studies are due to methodological reasons such as collecting small datasets or using different experimental designs or analytical approaches. Here, we propose that there is a deeper problem: these discrepancies are due to a theoretical misspecification. 

Most studies approach the neural representation of emotion as a “classification problem”. They assume each emotion category has a particular activation pattern that is shared across instances of that emotion and the analytical goal is to train models to predict emotion labels from brain data. They typically assume that brain activity underlying a given emotion category is the same across people and situations, but do not test those assumptions. Alternatively, we propose that understanding the brain basis of emotion is “a category construction problem” wherein emotion categories are dynamically constructed by the brain. From this perspective, the brain representations of emotion may be variable across individuals and situations. If so, then the scientific aim is to model how each person’s brain represents emotions using a more data-driven approach, and then examine whether the brain representation of emotion is shared across instances, or whether these representations vary by the individual and situation.

The goal of this project was to test the category construction approach. This required developing a novel analytical approach that models the full distribution of brain states while also examining how this distribution relates with emotion categories on a person-by-person basis. The researchers developed a novel framework that uses a variational autoencoder with a classifier to investigate brain-behavior relationships. The variational autoencoder models brain data in a low dimensional space (e.g. two dimensions), so researchers can visualize how latent brain states are distributed. This latent space can help reveal whether the brain-behavior relation is one-to-one, as is often assumed, or many-to-one, as expected by the category construction approach. The classifier component models how these latent brain states relate with behavior - for example, linearly or nonlinearly. They tested their framework on simulated data to show that putting more weight on supervision leads to significant distortions in the distribution of brain states from the ground-truth, particularly when there is a many-to-one mapping between brain states and behavioral labels (e.g., many brain states for “fear” or for “anger”). 

Testing this framework on a person-by-person basis required collecting a new dataset in which a lot of data was collected from each person, which in turn required developing a new stimulus set that could evoke instances of the same emotion categories dozens or more times in each person. In a behavioral study, the researchers curated a large (>700) set of stimuli to evoke emotions and had hundreds participants (N > 400) rate their emotional experiences in response to them. Strikingly, few stimuli reliably and exclusively evoked the same emotional response across most people. These findings challenge the conventional approach of averaging data across people per stimulus - which assumes that people experience the stimulus in the same way.

In the neuroimaging study, each participant viewed hundreds (300+) of those stimuli across four sessions with brain imaging (fMRI) and peripheral autonomic recordings (e.g., heart rate, respiration, and sweat responses), and again in four behavioral testing sessions (to record how they perceived and experienced the videos). The extensive sampling per person enabled researchers to analyze data at the level of each subject rather than averaging across groups. The researchers can now apply their novel framework to the collected data for each participant.

The research has had several broader impacts on the community. Code has been shared with the community and our analytical and broader theoretical framework can be extended to any domain of study in cognitive neuroscience. The project supported cross-training for psychology trainees in engineering and computational approaches, and for engineering trainees in experimental psychology and neuroscience. Over a dozen undergraduate students were trained in research methods including data collection/cleaning/management for behavioral, MRI, and peripheral autonomic data, study design and human subjects testing. The project fostered a transdisciplinary collaboration between psychologists, neuroscientists, and computer scientists. The project led to new teaching approaches that introduce advanced machine learning approaches in psychology and neuroscience for undergraduate and graduate students.
